Hi,

2009/9/13 Aidan Morgan <aidos@...>
>
>
> Thanks for the very interesting read. I am currently using kmedoid clustering for some work I am doing, and
> your writeup of your approach so far was very informative.


No problem. Like I say in the writeup I think there's probably not
much of a distinction between k-means and k-medoids for this problem.




> My similarity is based on behaviour, not on
> chromosome similarity, so I can't have an artifiical centroid - there is no way for me to measure it's
> behaviour.


It really depends on how you calculate behavioural similarity. In some
cases we know we have a very simple proxy for overall behaviour such
as the single end coordinate in a maze used in the novelty search
papers. In the more general case we know we can record the output
neuron signals at each timestep and that can potentially be used to
compare behavioural similarity, although quite how you compare the
output perhaps isn't always obvious. And as you say you could first
try to reduce dimensionality of the problem and then cluster based on
the location in the reduced space, this would be necessary where the
recorded output data is very large in size - but how you go about
reducing it's dimensionaility is unclear to me at this time.

Colin
